The '''Anticato''' (sometimes '''Anti-Cato'''; [[Latin]]: '''''Anticatones''''') was a [[polemic]] written by [[Julius Caesar]] in hostile reply to [[Cicero]]'s pamphlet praising [[Cato the Younger]]. The text is lost and survives only in fragments. [[Marcus Junius Brutus|Brutus]], dissatisfied with Cicero's work, wrote a second pamphlet in praise of Cato and called, simply, "Cato," which provoked a reply from [[Octavian]].<ref>[[Suetonius]], Life of Augustus 85.1 http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/suetonius/suet.aug.html#85</ref> Octavian's work is not known to have been called Anticato but must have been modeled on Caesar's reply to Cicero.
== Background == {{main|Cato the Younger}} Cato was a famously stubborn [[Stoicism|Stoic]], who came into conflict with Caesar at the [[Second Catilinarian conspiracy|Catiline conspiracy]] trial. Cato argued for capital punishment for [[Lucius Sergius Catilina]] and his conspirators, so as to set an example and discourage similar [[treason]]. Caesar argued for a private judgement and clemency. The Senate agreed with Cato, and the executions were carried out; the rebel army disbanded and fled. During the debate, however, Cato had called out Caesar for reading personal messages in the Senate; Caesar defended himself, saying he was only reading a [[love letter]]. Cato insisted on reading it, and to widespread dismay, it was what Caesar said—exposing his affair with [[Servilia (mother of Marcus Junius Brutus)|Servilia]], the half-sister of Cato. Servilia was forced to divorce.
Next, during the [[triumvirate]] of Caesar, [[Pompey]], and [[Marcus Licinius Crassus]], Cato interfered with Caesar's plans for a [[Roman triumph|triumph]] for himself, while supporting one for Pompey. Cato opposed Caesar's every political step afterward, in particular leading the opposition to Caesar's return to Rome in 49 BC without relinquishing his proconsulship. Caesar famously crossed the [[Rubicon]] and came to Rome regardless, sparking the Roman Civil War. When Caesar prevailed in the war and looked to seize power in Rome, Cato committed suicide.
Several leading Romans wrote works in posthumous praise or criticism of Cato. A famous [[panegyric]] by [[Cicero]] titled simply ''Cato'' led to Caesar writing his ''Anticato'' in response.

The '''approximate number system''' ('''ANS''') is a cognitive system that supports the estimation of the [[Magnitude (mathematics)|magnitude]] of a group without relying on language or symbols. The ANS is credited with the non-symbolic representation of all numbers greater than four, with lesser values being carried out by the [[parallel individuation system]], or object tracking system.<ref name="Piazza">{{cite journal|last=Piazza|first=M.|title=Neurocognitive start-up tools for symbolic number representations|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|year=2010|volume=14|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2010.09.008|pages=542–551}}</ref> Beginning in early infancy, the ANS allows an individual to detect differences in magnitude between groups. The precision of the ANS improves throughout childhood development and reaches a final adult level of approximately 15% accuracy, meaning an adult could distinguish 100 items versus 115 items without counting.<ref name="book">{{cite book|last=Sousa|first=David|title=Mind, Brain, and Education: Neuroscience Implications for the Classroom|year=2010|publisher=Solution Tree Press|isbn=9781935249634}}</ref> The ANS plays a crucial role in development of other numerical abilities, such as the concept of exact number and simple arithmetic. The precision level of a child's ANS has been shown to predict subsequent mathematical achievement in school.<ref name = "Mazzocco">{{cite journal|last=Mazzocco|first=M.M.M.|author2=Feigenson, L.|author3=Halberda, J.|title=Preschoolers' precision of the approximate number system predicts later school mathematics performance|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2011|volume=6|issue=9|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0023749|pages=e23749|pmid=21935362|pmc=3173357}}</ref> The ANS has been linked to the [[intraparietal sulcus]] of the brain.<ref name="Piazza2">{{cite journal|last=Piazza|first=M.|title=Tuning curves for approximate numerosity in the human parietal cortex|journal=Neuron|year=2004|volume=44|doi=10.1016/j.neuron.2004.10.014|pages=547–555}}</ref>
==History==
===Piaget's theory=== [[Jean Piaget]] was a Swiss [[developmental psychologist]] who devoted much of his life to studying how children learn. A book summarizing his theories on number cognition, ''The Child's Conception of Number'', was published in 1952.<ref name="book" /> Piaget's work supported the viewpoint that children do not have a stable representation of number until the age of six or seven. His theories indicate that mathematical knowledge is slowly gained and during infancy any concept of sets, objects, or calculation is absent.<ref name="book" />
===Challenging the Piagetian viewpoint=== Piaget's ideas pertaining to the absence of [[Numerical cognition|mathematical cognition]] at birth have been steadily challenged. The work of [[Rochel Gelman]] and [[C. Randy Gallistel]] among others in the 1970s suggested that preschoolers have intuitive understanding of the quantity of a [[Set (mathematics)|set]] and its conservation under non cardinality-related changes, expressing surprise when objects disappear without an apparent cause.<ref name="book" />
===Current theory=== Beginning as infants, people have an innate sense of approximate number that depends on the ratio between sets of objects.<ref name="cantlon">{{cite journal|last=Cantlon|first=JF|title=Functional Imaging of Numerical Processing in Adults and 4-y-old Children|journal=PLoS Biology|year=2006|volume=4|issue=5|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.0040125|pmid=16594732|pmc=1431577|pages=e125}}</ref> Throughout life the ANS becomes more developed, and people are able to distinguish between groups having smaller differences in magnitude.<ref name="hyde2">{{cite journal|last=Hyde|first=DC|title=Near-infrared spectroscopy shows right parietal specialization for number in pre-verbal infants.|journal=NeuroImage|year=2010|volume=53|issue=2|pages=647–652|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.06.030|pmid=20561591|pmc=2930081}}</ref> The ratio of distinction is defined by [[Weber–Fechner law|Weber's law]], which relates the different intensities of a [[Stimulus (physiology)|sensory stimulus]] that is being evaluated.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pessoa|first=L|author2=Desimone R.|title=From Humble Neural Beginnings Comes Knowledge of Numbers|journal=Neuron|year=2003|volume=37|issue=1|pages=4–6|doi=10.1016/s0896-6273(02)01179-0}}</ref> In the case of the ANS, as the ratio between the magnitudes increases, the ability to discriminate between the two quantities increases.
Today, some theorize that the ANS lays the foundation for higher-level arithmetical concepts. Research has shown that the same areas of the brain are active during non-symbolic number tasks in infants and both non-symbolic and more sophisticated symbolic number tasks in adults.<ref name="Piazza3">{{cite journal|last=Piazza|first=M|title=A magnitude code common to numerosity and number symbols in human intraparietal cortex.|journal=Neuron|year=2007|volume=53|issue=2|pages=293–305|doi=10.1016/j.neuron.2006.11.022}}</ref> These results could suggest that the ANS contributes over time to the development of higher-level numerical skills that activate the same part of the brain.
However, longitudinal studies do not necessarily find that non-symbolic abilities predict later symbolic abilities. Conversely, early symbolic number abilities have been found to predict later non-symbolic abilities, not vice versa as predicted.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Symbolic Number Abilities Predict Later Approximate Number System Acuity in Preschool Children|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0091839|journal = PLoS ONE|date = 2014-03-17|pmc = 3956743|pmid = 24637785|pages = e91839|volume = 9|issue = 3|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0091839|first = Christophe|last = Mussolin|first2 = Julie|last2 = Nys|first3 = Alain|last3 = Content|first4 = Jacqueline|last4 = Leybaert}}</ref> In adults for example, non-symbolic number abilities do not always explain mathematics achievement.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Non-verbal number acuity correlates with symbolic mathematics achievement: but only in children|journal = Psychonomic Bulletin & Review|date = 2011-12-01|issn = 1531-5320|pmid = 21898191|pages = 1222–1229|volume = 18|issue = 6|doi = 10.3758/s13423-011-0154-1|first = Matthew|last = Inglis|first2 = Nina|last2 = Attridge|first3 = Sophie|last3 = Batchelor|first4 = Camilla|last4 = Gilmore}}</ref>
==Neurological basis== Brain imaging studies have identified the [[parietal lobe]] as being a key brain region for numerical cognition.<ref name="Dehaene">{{cite journal|last=Dehaene|first=S|title=Three parietal circuits for number processing.|journal=Cognitive Neuropsychology|year=2003|volume=20|issue=3|pages=487–506|doi=10.1080/02643290244000239|pmid=20957581}}</ref> Specifically within this lobe is the [[intraparietal sulcus]] which is "active whenever we think about a number, whether spoken or written, as a word or as an [[Arabic numerals|Arabic digit]], or even when we inspect a set of objects and think about its cardinality".<ref name="book" /> When comparing groups of objects, activation of the intraparietal sulcus is greater when the difference between groups is numerical rather than an alternative factor, such as differences in shape or size.<ref name="cantlon" /> This indicates that the intraparietal sulcus plays an active role when the ANS is employed to approximate magnitude.
Parietal lobe brain activity seen in adults is also observed during infancy during non-verbal numerical tasks, suggesting that the ANS is present very early in life.<ref name="hyde2" /> A neuroimaging technique, [[fNIR|functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy]], was performed on infants revealing that the parietal lobe is specialized for number representation before the development of language.<ref name="hyde2" /> This indicates that numerical cognition may be initially reserved to the right hemisphere of the brain and becomes bilateral through experience and the development of complex number representation.
It has been shown that the intraparietal sulcus is activated independently of the type of task being performed with the number. The intensity of activation is dependent on the difficulty of the task, with the intraparietal sulcus showing more intense activation when the task is more difficult.<ref name="book" /> In addition, studies in monkeys have shown that individual [[neuron]]s can fire preferentially to certain numbers over others.<ref name="book" /> For example, a neuron could fire at maximum level every time a group of four objects is seen, but will fire less to a group three or five objects.
==Pathology==
===Damage to intraparietal sulcus=== Damage done to parietal lobe, specifically in the left hemisphere, can produce difficulties in counting and other simple arithmetic.<ref name="book" /> Damage directly to the intraparietal sulcus has been shown to cause [[acalculia]], a severe disorder in mathematical cognition.<ref name="cantlon" /> Symptoms vary based the location of damage, but can include the inability to perform simple calculations or to decide that one number is larger than another.<ref name="book" /> [[Gerstmann syndrome]], a disease resulting in lesions in the left parietal and [[temporal lobe]]s, results in acalculia symptoms and further confirms the importance of the parietal region in the ANS.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ashkenazi|first=S|title=Basic Numerical Processing in Left Intraparietal Sulcus (IPS) Acalculia.|journal=Cortex|year=2008|volume=44|issue=4|doi=10.1016/j.cortex.2007.08.008|pages=439–448|pmid=18387576}}</ref>
===Developmental delays=== A syndrome known as [[dyscalculia]] is seen in individuals who have unexpected difficulty understanding numbers and arithmetic despite adequate education and social environments.<ref name="molko">{{cite journal|last=Molko|first=N|title=Functional and structural alterations of the intraparietal sulcus in a developmental dyscalculia of genetic origin|journal=Neuron|year=2003|volume=40|issue=4|doi=10.1016/s0896-6273(03)00670-6|pages=847–858}}</ref> This syndrome can manifest in several different ways from the inability to assign a quantity to Arabic numerals to difficulty with times tables. Dyscalculia can result in children falling significantly behind in school, regardless of having normal intelligence levels.
In some instances, such as [[Turner syndrome]], the onset of dyscalculia is genetic. Morphological studies have revealed abnormal lengths and depths of the right intraparietal sulcus in individuals suffering from Turner syndrome.<ref name="molko" /> Brain imaging in children exhibiting symptoms of dyscalculia show less [[gray matter]] or less activation in the intraparietal regions stimulated normally during mathematical tasks.<ref name="book" /> Additionally, impaired ANS acuity has been shown to differentiate children with dyscalculia from their normally-developing peers with low maths achievement.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mazzocco|first=M.M.M.|author2=Feigenson, L.|author3=Halberda, J.|title=Impaired Acuity of the Approximate Number System Underlies Mathematical Learning Disability(Dyscalculia)|journal=Child Development|year=2011|volume=82|issue=4|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2011.01608.x|pages=1224–1237|pmid=21679173|pmc=4411632}}</ref>
==Further research and theories==
===Impact of the visual cortex=== The intraparietal region relies on several other brain systems to accurately perceive numbers. When using the ANS we must view the sets of objects in order to evaluate their magnitude. The [[primary visual cortex]] is responsible for disregarding irrelevant information, such as the size or shape of the objects.<ref name="book" /> Certain visual cues can sometimes affect how the ANS functions.
Arranging the items differently can alter the effectiveness of the ANS. One arrangement proven to influence the ANS is visual nesting, or placing the objects within one another. This configuration affects the ability to distinguish each item and add them together at the same time. The difficulty results in underestimation of the magnitude present in the set or a longer amount of time needed to perform an estimate.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chesney|first=DL|title=Visual Nesting Impacts Approximate Number System Estimation|journal=Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics|year=2012|volume=74|issue=6}}</ref>
Another visual representation that affects the ANS is the [[Spatial-numerical association of response codes|spatial-numerical association response code]], or the SNARC effect. The SNARC effect details the tendency of larger numbers to be responded to faster by the right hand and lower numbers by the left hand, suggesting that the magnitude of a number is linked to a spatial representation.<ref name= "ren">{{cite journal|last=Ren|first=P|title=Size matters: non-numerical magnitude affects the spatial coding of response|journal=PLOS ONE|year=2011|volume=6|issue=8|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0023553|pages=e23553|pmid=21853151|pmc=3154948}}</ref> Dehaene and other researchers believe this effect is caused by the presence of a “mental number line” in which small numbers appear on the left and increase as you move right.<ref name="ren" /> The SNARC effect indicates that the ANS works more effectively and accurately if the larger set of objects is on the right and the smaller on the left.
===Development and mathematical performance=== Although the ANS is present in infancy before any numerical education, research has shown a link between people's mathematical abilities and the accuracy in which they approximate the magnitude of a set. This correlation is supported by several studies in which school-aged children's ANS abilities are compared to their mathematical achievements. At this point the children have received training in other mathematical concepts, such as exact number and arithmetic.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Halberda|first=J|title=Individual differences in non-verbal number acuity correlate with maths achievement|journal=Nature|year=2008|volume=455|issue=7213|doi=10.1038/nature07246|pmid=18776888|pages=665–8}}</ref> More surprisingly, ANS precision before any formal education accurately predicts better math performance. A study involving 3-5 year old children revealed that ANS acuity corresponds to better mathematical cognition while remaining independent of factors that may interfere, such as reading ability and the use of Arabic numerals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Libertus|first=ME|title=Preschool acuity of the approximate number system correlates with school math ability|journal=Developmental Science|year=2011|volume=14|issue=6|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2011.01080.x|pages=1292–1300|pmc=3338171}}</ref>
===ANS in animals=== {{Main|Number sense in animals}} Many species of animals exhibit the ability to assess and compare magnitude. This skill is believed to be a product of the ANS. Research has revealed this capability in both vertebrate and non-vertebrate animals including birds, mammals, fish, and even insects.<ref name= "agrillo">{{cite journal|last=Agrillo|first=Christian|title=Evidence for Two Numerical Systems That Are Similar in Humans and Guppies|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2012|volume=7|issue=2|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0031923|pages=e31923|pmid=22355405|pmc=3280231}}</ref> In primates, implications of the ANS have been steadily observed through research. One study involving lemurs showed that they were able to distinguish groups of objects based only on numerical differences, suggesting that humans and other primates utilize a similar numerical processing mechanism.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Merritt|first=Dustin|title=Numerical rule-learning in ring-tailed Lemurs (Lemur catta) |journal=Frontiers in Psychology|year=2011|volume=2|issue=23|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2011.00023 }}</ref>
In a study comparing students to guppies, both the fish and students performed the numerical task almost identically.<ref name="agrillo" /> The ability for the test groups to distinguish large numbers was dependent on the ratio between them, suggesting the ANS was involved. Such results seen when testing guppies indicate that the ANS may have been evolutionarily passed down through many species.<ref name="agrillo" />
==Applications in society==
===Implications for the classroom=== Understanding how the ANS affects students' learning could be beneficial for teachers and parents. The following tactics have been suggested by neuroscientists to utilize the ANS in school:<ref name="book" /> *Counting or abacus games *Simple board games *Computer-based number association games *Teacher sensitivity and different teaching methods for different learners Such tools are most helpful in training the number system when the child is at an earlier age. Children coming from a disadvantaged background with risk of arithmetic problems are especially impressionable by these tactics.<ref name="book" />

In Western [[music]] and [[music theory]], '''augmentation''' (from [[Late Latin]] ''augmentare'', to increase) is the lengthening of a [[Musical note|note]] or [[Interval (music)|interval]]. Augmentation is a compositional device where a [[melody]], theme or motif is presented in longer note-values than were previously used. Augmentation is also the term for the proportional lengthening of the value of individual note-shapes in older notation by coloration, by use of a sign of proportion, or by a notational symbol such as the modern dot. A major or perfect [[Interval (music)|interval]] that is widened by a chromatic semitone is an augmented interval, and the process may be called augmentation. ==Augmentation in composition== A melody or series of [[Musical note|note]]s is ''augmented'' if the lengths of the notes are prolonged; augmentation is thus the opposite of [[diminution]], where note values are shortened. A melody originally consisting of four quavers ([[eighth note]]s) for example, is augmented if it later appears with four crotchets ([[quarter note]]s) instead. This technique is often used in [[counterpoint|contrapuntal]] music, as in the "[[canon (music)|canon]] by augmentation" ("''per augmentationem''"), in which the notes in the following voice or voices are longer than those in the leading voice, usually twice the original length. The music of [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] provides examples of this application:[[File:Bach, Vom Himmel Hoch canonic variations, BWV 769, Variation 5.wav|thumb|Bach, Vom Himmel Hoch canonic variations, BWV 769, Variation 5]][[File:Bach, Vom Himmel Hoch canonic variations, BWV 769, Variation 6.png|thumb|center|500px|Bach, Vom Himmel Hoch canonic variations, BWV 769, Variation 5]] Other ratios of augmentation, such as 1:3 (tripled note values) and 1:4 (quadrupled note values), are also possible. A [[motif (music)|motif]] is also augmented through expanding its [[duration (music)|duration]]. Augmentation may also be found in later, non-contrapuntal pieces, such as the [[Symphony No. 6 (Beethoven)|Pastoral Symphony]] (Symphony No. 6) of [[Beethoven]], where the melodic figure first heard in the second violins at the start of the "Storm" movement ("''Die Sturm''"):[[File:Pastoral Symphony Storm.wav|thumb|Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 3-8]][[File:Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 3-8.png|thumb|center|500px|Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 3-8]] -is heard again in an augmented and transposed version in the same movement’s closing ten bars:[[File:Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 146-155.wav|thumb|Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 146-155]][[File:Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 146-155.png|thumb|center|500px|Beethoven Symphony No 6, fourth movement, bars 146-155]] Examples of augmentation may be found in the [[musical development|development sections]] of [[sonata form]] movements, particularly in the symphonies of [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]] and [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]] and in the protean [[leitmotifs]] in [[Wagner]]’s operas, which undergo all kinds of transformation as the characters change and develop through the unfolding drama. "Leitmotifs accumulate meaning, through expanding and fulfilling their musical potential." Scruton, R. (2016, p.204) the Ring of Truth: The Wuisdom of Wagner's Ring of the Nibelung." London, Allen Lane. In “Doctor Gradus ad Parnassum”, the first movement of his [[Children's Corner|''Children’s Corner'']] Suite, [[Debussy]] exploits augmentation in a humorous vein. It opens with a vigorous parody of a technical study by a pedagogical composer such as [[Muzio Clementi|Clementi]],Dawes, F. (1969, p34) Debussy Piano Music. London, BBC publications. involving a seemingly perpetual stream of fast semiquavers:[[File:Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 1-3.wav|thumb|Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 1-3]][[File:Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 1-3.png|thumb|center|500px|Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 1-3]] In bar 33, this energetic movement subsides, leading to a dreamy passage in the key of D flat, where the opening figures of the piece move at half speed:[[File:Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 36-43.wav|thumb|Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 36-43]][[File:Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 36-43.png|thumb|center|500px|Debussy, "Dr Gradus" from Childrens Corner, bars 36-43]] According to Frank Dawes, in this piece “An amusing picture of a child practising is conjured up, beginning with the best of intentions, growing weary and plainly yawning with boredom in the D flat section.” [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQOe2s4oDuQ Listen.] == Augmentation in notation == [[Image:dotted notes3.svg|right|frame|Dotted notes and their equivalent durations. The curved lines, called [[Tie (music)|ties]], add the note values together.]] {{main|Dotted note}} == Augmentation of intervals == [[Image:Augmented octave on C.png|thumb|Augmented octave on C. {{audio|Minor ninth on C.mid|Play}}]] An interval is augmented if it is widened by a [[chromatic semitone]]. Thus an [[augmented fifth]], for example, is a chromatic semitone wider than the [[perfect fifth]]. The standard abbreviations for augmented intervals are AX, such that an augmented third = A3. {| cellpadding="2" style="border: 1px solid darkgray; margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ '''Augmented intervals on C''' |- align="center" ! width="140" | [[Augmented unison]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented second]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented third]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented fourth]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented fifth]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented sixth]] ! width="140" | [[Augmented seventh]] |- border="0" | [[Image:Augmented unison on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented second on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented third on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented fourth on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented fifth on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented sixth on C.png|125px]] | [[Image:Augmented seventh on C.png|125px]] |- align="center" | {{Audio|Minor second on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Minor third on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Perfect fourth on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Tritone on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Minor sixth on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Minor seventh on C.mid|Play}} || {{Audio|Perfect octave on C.mid|Play}} |} A good example of this can be seen in the left hand part of [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin's]] famous E minor prelude [[Opus number|Op]]. 28, No. 4.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} Many of the [[chord progression|chord sequences]] change with the top or bottom note augmenting or diminishing the next chord as the music progresses. {| style="float: right; border: 1px solid #BBB; margin: .46em 0 0 .2em;" |- style="font-size: 86%;" |+ | valign="top" |[[Image:Augmented triad on C.png|150px]]
Augmented triad on C
{{Audio|Augmented triad on C.mid|play}} |} {| style="float: right; border: 1px solid #BBB; margin: .46em 0 0 .2em;" |- style="font-size: 86%;" |+ | valign="top" |[[Image:Augmented dominant seventh chord.png|150px]]
Augmented dominant seventh
chord on C {{audio|Augmented dominant seventh chord.mid|Play}} |} [[Image:Whole tone scale on C.png|thumb|250px|right|[[Whole tone scale]] on C {{audio|Whole tone scale on C.ogg|Play}}.]] An [[augmented chord]] is one which contains an augmented interval, almost invariably the 5th of the chord. An [[augmented triad]] is a [[Major chord|major triad]] whose fifth has been raised by a chromatic semitone; it is the principal harmony of the [[whole tone scale]].{{-}} ==See also== * [[Interval (music)|List of musical intervals]] * [[List of pitch intervals]] ==Sources== {{reflist|refs= Benward & Saker (2003). ''Music: In Theory and Practice, Vol. I'', p.54. {{ISBN|978-0-07-294262-0}}. Forte, Allen (1979/1962). ''Tonal Harmony in Concept & Practice'', p.391. Third edition. {{ISBN|0-03-020756-8}}. {{cite web|last=Bullivant|first=Roger|title=Augmentation (ii)|url=http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/53687|work=Grove Music Online|publisher=Oxford Music Online|accessdate=August 2011}} (subscription needed) "Augmentation and diminution" in the ''Harvard Dictionary of Music'', 2nd ed. rev. and enlarged (1969). Willi Apel, ed. Cambridge, Massachusetts: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press Jeppesen, Knud. ''Counterpoint: The Polyphonic Vocal Style of the Sixteenth Century''. trans. Glen Haydon. New York: Dover Publications. 1992. {{ISBN|978-0-486-27036-4}}. p. 235 }} ==External links== * [http://www.mutopiaproject.org/cgibin/piece-info.cgi?id=468 Prelude in E minor, Op. 28, No. 4] at The [[Mutopia Project]]. Deer Hill in [[Cornwall on Hudson]] | map = USA New York#USA | map_image = | map_size = 300 | map_caption = Location of Black Rock Forest within New York State | relief = 1 | location = [[Orange County, New York|Orange]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|41|24|29|N|74|01|18|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_sqmi = 6.1 | area_ref = | elevation = {{convert|1402|ft|m|abbr=on}} | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = | named_for = [[Magnetite]] deposits in forest{{cite web |title=Geology |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/geology.html |accessdate=January 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702053110/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/geology.html |archivedate=July 2, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = Black Rock Forest Consortium | owner = | website = [http://www.blackrockforest.org/ Black Rock Forest Consortium] | embedded = }} '''Black Rock Forest''' is a {{convert|3870|acre|km2|adj=on}}{{cite web |title=About the Forest |url=http://blackrockforest.org/about-1 |accessdate=August 29, 2016}} forest and biological field station maintained by Black Rock Forest Consortium. It is located in the western [[Hudson Highlands]] region of the [[U.S. state]] of New York, in [[Orange County, New York|Orange County]], mostly in the [[Administrative divisions of New York#Town|town]] of [[Cornwall, New York|Cornwall]], with the southern fringe overlapping into the neighboring town of [[Highlands, New York|Highlands]]. First established by a local resident in 1928, the forest was the property of [[Harvard University]] until 1989. The Consortium has invested heavily in facilities to not only improve its research and educational missions but promote [[sustainability]], erecting several [[green building]]s in the middle of the forest with guest facilities, classrooms and laboratories. Its educational facilities are used by groups at every level, from the primary [[elementary education|elementary]] [[grade level|grades]] to college undergraduates. Over 400 papers have been published from research done in the forest. ==History== The current forest began to grow about 14,000 years ago, with the [[Holocene glacial retreat|retreat]] of the [[glacier]]s at the end of the [[Wisconsin glaciation|last Ice Age]]. Originally, like many post-glacial forests, it consisted of [[evergreen]] [[conifer]]s such as [[spruce]] and [[fir]], but as the climate warmed they gave way to the [[deciduous]] species of [[oak]] and maple that now predominate.{{cite web |title=Forest History |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/ForestHistory.html |accessdate=January 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509142826/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/ForestHistory.html |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Like much of the Highlands, the land now part of Black Rock had been heavily impacted by human usage. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native]] communities hunted the forest extensively, built large settlements and started [[forest fire]]s to clear sections of the woods and prevent larger natural ones. After [[European colonization of the Americas|colonization]] of the [[Hudson Valley]] in 1690, the impact becomes more evident to the contemporary eye. During the last years of the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] the [[Continental Army]] used the Continental Road that runs through the center of the property to get between [[West Point]] and its [[New Windsor Cantonment State Historic Site|encampment]] at [[New Windsor, New York|New Windsor]]. Spy Rock got its name from its use by Continental soldiers as a lookout point where they could monitor [[Newburgh Bay]] for any signs of British activity on the strategically important [[Hudson River]].{{cite book |title=New York Walk Book |year=1998 |edition=Seventh|publisher=[[New York - New Jersey Trail Conference]] |location= [[Mahwah, New Jersey|Mahwah, NJ]] |isbn=1-880775-30-1 |page=312 |others=Illustrations by Robert L. Dickinson and Jack Fagan.}} Throughout the 19th century it saw extensive [[logging]] and mining, with some homesteads and farms established in its lower-lying portions. Only one building, the 1834 Chatsfield stone house, remains today. As the forest land began to decline in value with the depletion of its productive resources, various tracts were bought by the Stillman family in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In 1928, enough land had been acquired for Dr. Ernest Stillman to officially create Black Rock Forest for research and demonstration purposes. He hoped to restore it to productive use again through newly developed practical [[forestry]] techniques, as well as leaving plenty of undisturbed land available for use in [[silviculture|silvicultural]] research. To this end he hired a forester, Hal Tryon, and a small crew to cull unwanted species and poorly growing trees from wanted ones. The forest improved considerably, and upon his death in 1949 Stillman [[bequest|left]] the forest to his ''[[alma mater]]'', [[Harvard University]], for the continuation of its purposes. During Harvard's ownership of the forest, 75 [[Academic publishing#Scholarly paper|scientific papers]] were published based on research in it. [[Hiking]] [[trail]]s were also developed in the forest under the auspices of the [[New York - New Jersey Trail Conference]]. During the late 1960s and 1970s the Forest faced its biggest threat, as a massive power plant proposed for nearby [[Storm King Mountain (New York)|Storm King Mountain]] by [[Consolidated Edison]] would have flooded most of it to build a large [[reservoir (water)|reservoir]]. That plan was eventually abandoned in 1982 after a landmark environmental lawsuit.''Ibid.'', 305. Since Harvard also owns the eponymous forest closer to campus in [[Petersham, Massachusetts]], in 1981 it asked another alumnus, William Golden, what he thought should be done with Black Rock. He suggested that there were plenty of local organizations which might be able to derive the same benefit from it, and approached them about forming a [[consortium]] or similar group to take over from Harvard. Many were enthusiastic about the idea but lacked enough funds to contribute even a share of the purchase price. Golden decided to purchase the land himself in 1989 and give it to a newly created Black Rock Forest Preserve, which in turn leases it to the Black Rock Forest Consortium. Harvard donated the purchase price to the forest as the beginning of an [[Financial endowment|endowment]], and Golden added to that with more of his own money.{{cite web |title=History of the Consortium |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/history.html |accessdate=January 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206061035/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/history.html |archivedate=December 6, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} ==Geography== The forest is nestled in an area roughly bounded by [[U.S. Route 9W|US 9W]] to the east and Angola Road (which it does not reach) on the north. To the southwest, a small portion, the former Mineral Springs Nature Preserve, protrudes to a public access point on Old Mineral Springs Road. A large tract along the western boundary, and a smaller one to the east, are designated as ecological reserves within the forest.{{cite web |url= http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/Black_Rock_GIS_Map.pdf |title= Black Rock GIS Map |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518111215/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/Black_Rock_GIS_Map.pdf |archivedate= May 18, 2008 |df= mdy-all }}  {{small|(72.4 KB)}}, retrieved January 26, 2008. [[File:Mineral Springs Falls in Black Rock Forest, NY.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Mineral Springs Falls]] Most public access comes from Route 9W, near the lowest portions of the land, and many of the research and educational facilities are located in that north central area. To the south, in the Highlands portion of the forest, the land rises over a thousand feet (300 m) to several peaks, including the eponymous 1,402-foot (427 m) Black Rock with its [[observation tower]] and Spy Rock, at 1,463 feet (446 m) the highest point in the Town of Highlands and the highest peak in the Highlands west of the [[Hudson River]].[[Schunemunk Mountain]], Orange County's highest peak at 1,664 feet (507 m), while located a short distance to the west, is geologically distinct from the Highlands and not considered part of them. There are seven ponds in the forest, all of which form part of the village of [[Cornwall on Hudson]]'s [[water supply system]] save Sutherland Pond, the only one in which visitors are allowed to swim.{{cite web |title=Usage Policies |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/UsagePolicies.html |accessdate=January 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509161438/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-forest/UsagePolicies.html |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} The ponds drain into an unnamed stream that crosses the village and empties into [[Moodna Creek]] near where it joins the Hudson; Sutherland gives rise to [[Mineral Springs Brook]], which flows out to the scenic Mineral Springs Falls near the western end of the forest and then to Moodna Creek's main tributary, [[Woodbury Creek]]. The forest is buffered by other, nearby [[protected area]]s in two directions, with [[Storm King State Park]] on the east across Route 9W and the large [[United States Military Academy]] reservation directly to the south. In other directions the large, minimally developed tracts of private landowners serve as a buffer. ===Roads and trails=== A network of old logging and mining roads, including the Continental Road, still exists and provides access to many points in the central region of the park. They are closed to all motor-vehicle use save that authorized by the consortium for its members; they are open to bicycles and foot traffic and [[trail blazing|marked]] as part of the forest's trail system. Together with cut footpaths, the roads provide over 30 miles (50 km) of trails in Black Rock Forest.''New York Walk Book'', 313 Most are short routes between the roads and other trails or spurs to various overlooks running less than two miles (3 km) in total length. The two exceptions are the Scenic and Stillman trails, backbone routes across the park in different directions, both also carrying the long-distance [[Highlands Trail]] for all or most of their lengths. The Scenic Trail, the longest in the forest at 5.9 miles (9.5 km), runs from its western [[trailhead]] on Old Mineral Springs Road near the falls atop the ridge past Spy Rock to end at a junction with the Stillman near Mount Misery.''Ibid.'', 317-18. The Stillman Trail, named for the forest's founder, is actually a continuation of a trail that begins in Cornwall on Hudson and goes over Storm King, then crosses 9W into the forest. It runs 5.3 miles (8.5 km) across the forest and over Black Rock to end at an overlook to [[Schunemunk Mountain]] and [[Mountainville, New York|Mountainville]] near the forest's western boundary.''Ibid.'', 319-21. ==Geology== The forest is one of the northernmost sections of the [[New York-New Jersey Highlands|Highlands Province]] of the [[Appalachian Mountains]]. The [[Precambrian]] [[gneiss]] [[bedrock]] in the forest is the oldest in New York State, formed 1.1 billion-1.3 billion years ago and first uplifted during the [[Taconic Orogeny]] 460 million-440 million years ago. The [[Acadian Orogeny|Acadian]] and [[Alleghenian Orogeny|Alleghenian]] orogenies further shaped the mountains to their present form, and then the glaciers and erosion wore them down. Within the gneiss can be found several other minerals: [[feldspar]], [[quartz]], [[pyroxene]] and [[mica]]. Black bands within the bedrock come from the mineral that gave the forest its name: [[magnetite]], a source of iron. Two [[Aviation accidents and incidents|plane crashes]] on the Hill of Pines, less than 600 feet (180 m) apart, are believed to have occurred because of the mineral's influence on the aircraft [[compass]]es. ==Biological resources== Black Rock Forest's flora and fauna are part of the [[Northeastern coastal forests]] [[ecoregion]].{{cite journal |author = Olson, D. M |author2=E. Dinerstein |title = Terrestrial Ecoregions of the World: A New Map of Life on Earth |journal = [[BioScience]] |year = 2001 |volume=51 |issue=11 |pages= 933–938 |url = http://worldwildlife.org/science/wildfinder/ |doi = 10.1641/0006-3568(2001)051[0933:TEOTWA]2.0.CO;2 |display-authors=etal}} ===Flora=== [[Botany|Botanists]] working in the forest have identified several distinct plant communities, including 60 species of tree,{{cite web |url= http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/TreeSpeciesList.pdf |title= Trees of Black Rock Forest |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518095751/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/TreeSpeciesList.pdf |archivedate= May 18, 2008 |df= mdy-all }}  {{small|(114 KB)}}, retrieved January 26, 2008. within it, spread among six different regions. The most widespread is an [[oak]] forest found in the drier lowlands, where red oak, the most common [[canopy (forest)|canopy]] tree on the property, predominates along with maples, hickory and [[Betula lenta|black birch]]. Some [[chestnut]]s, once the dominant canopy tree before the [[chestnut blight]], survive as well. [[Shrub]]s include [[Kalmia latifolia|mountain laurel]] and [[witch-hazel]].''Ibid.'', 310-11. The same trees can also be found in the [[wetlands]]. More associate species show up, particularly [[sugar maple]], as well as [[beech]], [[basswood]] and [[Liquidambar|sweetgum]]. The [[understory]] add [[ironwood]], [[striped maple]] and [[spicebush]]. In flooded areas, [[red maple]] and [[alder]], which can tolerate the water, are dominant along with [[leatherleaf]] and [[sphagnum]]. A few [[gray birch]] are found along the edges of ponds, and [[eastern hemlock]] can be found along some of the streams, cooling the water with its shade. Higher up the ridges, as the soils thin, the dominant oaks are the [[chestnut oak|chestnut]] and scrub oak varieties found on most montane sites in the Highlands. [[Pitch pine]] cannot flourish anywhere else in the forest except in the thin soils found here, and on the bare rocks sensitive [[lichen]]s, [[moss]]es and [[grass]]es take hold where they can. A 2003 study by the [[Brooklyn Botanical Garden]] identified 688 species of [[vascular plant]]s in the forest over an eight-year period. It found ten species rare in New York, and six considered endangered by the state, including [[Aristolochia|Virginia snakeroot]] and [[Utricularia inflata|swollen bladderoot]]{{cite journal |last=Barringer |first=Kerry |author2=Clemants, Stephen |date=October 2003 |title=The vascular flora of Black Rock Forest, Cornwall, New York |journal=The Journal of the Torrey Botanical Society |volume=130 |issue=4 |pages=292–308 |id= |url=http://apt.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=get-abstract&doi=10.1043%2F1095-5674(2003)130%5B0292%3ATVFOBR%5D2.0.CO%3B2&ct=1 |accessdate= January 29, 2008 |quote=The flora of Black Rock Forest in Cornwall, New York, contains 688 species of vascular plants. Between 1990 and 1998, vascular plant specimens were collected in the Forest as part of a series of studies of the vegetation and flora. The flora includes ten state rarities. Of the six species in the Forest considered imperiled in the state, ''[[Aristolochia]] serpentaria'' and ''[[Utricularia inflata]]'' are extant |doi=10.2307/3557547 |jstor=3557547 |publisher=Torrey Botanical Society}} ===Fauna=== As in other [[woodland]]s in the Eastern United States, [[white-tailed deer]] are the most abundant [[mammal]] within Black Rock Forest, providing ample hunting opportunities. Common associate species like [[fox]]es, [[mink]], [[striped skunk]]s and [[raccoon]]s are also common, as are [[rodent]] species like [[squirrel]]s, [[chipmunk]]s and [[vole]]s. Some [[bat]] species also have taken up residence.{{cite web |url= http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/MammalsSpeciesList.pdf |title= Mammal Species List |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518095711/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/MammalsSpeciesList.pdf |archivedate= May 18, 2008 |df= mdy-all }}  {{small|(18.0 KB)}}, Retrieved January 27, 2008 [[Coyote]]s have made a comeback since 1985, and there have been signs of [[beaver]] activity although the animals themselves have rarely been seen. Many [[reptile]]s and [[amphibian]]s common to Eastern forests are well represented. These include several [[salamander]] species, a few [[frog]]s, the [[American toad]], and the [[Terrapene carolina carolina|Eastern box]] and [[painted turtle|painted]] [[turtle]]s. Some poisonous snakes have been found, although [[garter snake]]s and other non-hazardous species are more common.{{cite web |url= http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/ReptilesAmphibiansSpeciesList.pdf |title= Reptiles and Amphibians List |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518095647/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/ReptilesAmphibiansSpeciesList.pdf |archivedate= May 18, 2008 |df= mdy-all }}  {{small|(229 KB)}}, Retrieved January 27, 2008 Woodland birds like [[ruffed grouse]] and [[wild turkey]] are dominant among avian species, with [[Canada goose|Canada geese]] and [[mallard duck]]s conspicuous in and near the ponds. Smaller birds include the [[downy woodpecker|downy]] and [[hairy woodpecker|hairy]] [[woodpecker]]s. All are prey for common [[predator]] species like the [[red-tailed hawk]], [[Cooper's hawk]] and [[barred owl]].{{cite web |url= http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/BirdSpeciesList.pdf |title= Bird Species List |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080725170720/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/BirdSpeciesList.pdf |archivedate= July 25, 2008 |df= mdy-all }}  {{small|(62.7 KB)}}, Retrieved January 27, 2008. Most insect species have not been formally counted. The [[American Museum of Natural History]], a consortium member, has counted 296 [[spider]] species in the forest as of 2005,{{cite web |title=A List of Spiders |url=http://research.amnh.org/entomology/blackrock2/check_list.htm |year=2005 |accessdate=January 27, 2008}} and the following year a Harvard study found 33 [[ant]] species and projected a possible 58 in the forest.{{cite journal |last=Ellison |first=Aaron |author2=Record, Sydne |author3=Arguello, Alexander |author4=Gotelli, Nicholas J. |date=August 2007 |title=Rapid Inventory of the Ant Assemblage in a Temperate Hardwood Forest: Species Composition and Assessment of Sampling Methods |journal=Environmental Entomology |volume=36 |issue=4 |page=10 |id= |url=http://esa.publisher.ingentaconnect.com/content/esa/envent/2007/00000036/00000004/art00014 |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |quote=A total of 33 species in 14 genera were collected and identified ... Using new, unbiased estimators, we project that 38-58 ant species are likely to occur at Black Rock Forest. |doi=10.1603/0046-225X(2007)36[766:RIOTAA]2.0.CO;2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130103164747/http://esa.publisher.ingentaconnect.com/content/esa/envent/2007/00000036/00000004/art00014 |archivedate=January 3, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} ==Management== Black Rock Forest is run on a daily basis by a staff of ten headed by Executive Director, Dr. William Schuster.{{cite web |title=Staff |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/staff.html |accessdate=January 31, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118044154/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/staff.html |archivedate=January 18, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} They report to the consortium's [[board of trustees|board]], which is composed of six officers, a representative of each member organization, 13 directors-at-large and the seven members of the Black Rock Forest Preserve board. It is currently chaired by Sibyl Golden, who also edits ''Black Rock Forest News'', the consortium's quarterly [[newsletter]]. Columbia professor Kevin Griffin serves as president.{{cite web |title=Board |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/Board.html |accessdate=January 31, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725170950/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/the-consortium/board.html |archivedate=July 25, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} ===Land usage=== The forest is free and open to the public daily for hiking and mountain biking, but within strict rules in order to preserve its value as a research and educational facility. No motor vehicles other than those authorized by the forest are allowed on its roads, and then only within a 10 mph (16 km/h) [[speed limit]]. The forest closes at dusk daily; no [[camping]] is permitted except for occasional [[Leave No Trace|light-impact]] stays. Research plots, when clearly marked, are not to be disturbed. Hikers are asked to stay on marked trails and refrain from [[Bushwhacker|bushwhacking]]. Swimming and [[angling|fishing]] are permitted only in Sutherland Pond and Mineral Springs Brook. Only members of the Black Rock Fish and Game Club are allowed to [[hunting|hunt]] in the forest during New York State [[firearm]] deer season in late fall; the forest is closed to the public during that period. ===Facilities=== During the Stillman and Harvard eras, the forest administration worked out of what is now known as the Old Forest Headquarters, on Continental Avenue, just across Route 9W from one of the main access points. It can still house 15 guests. It also has a lawn for recreational activities, a tree and shrub [[Nursery (horticulture)|nursery]], [[weather station]], storage barn and woodshop.{{cite web |title=Facilities and Resources |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/Facilities-and-Resources/index.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121184445/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/Facilities-and-Resources/index.html |archivedate=November 21, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} When the Consortium took over, it decided to build several facilities to allow education and research to take place in the forest itself, the first new construction in the forest since the 19th century. All are [[green building]]s, in keeping with the forest's mission,{{cite web |title=Green building and smart features |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/index.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121184450/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/index.html |archivedate=November 21, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} that have won their architects some awards.{{cite web |title=Awards |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/Awards.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206054719/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/Awards.html |archivedate=December 6, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} The main building is the Center for Science and Education, a 9,000-square foot (810 m²) structure erected in 1999 with [[grant (money)|grant]]s from the [[National Science Foundation]], [[Kresge Foundation]] and other donors. It has a wet and dry [[laboratory]], 1,150 square feet (104 m²) of classrooms (with labs of their own) designed for levels from [[kindergarten]] through undergraduate, and space for up to 60 visitors to stay overnight. The 700-square foot (63 m²) dry lab also has [[refrigerator]]s, [[freezer]]s, [[centrifuge]]s, distilled water and a [[fume hood]]. [[Archive]]d data from forest research and observation goes back to 1930 in some cases.{{cite web |title=Data Resources |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/DataResources/index.html |accessdate=January 31, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206055037/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/DataResources/index.html |archivedate=December 6, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Wired and [[wireless Internet|wireless]] Internet access is available.{{cite web |title=Spaces for Learning |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/teacher-student-resources/EducationalResources/Spaces.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206055457/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/teacher-student-resources/EducationalResources/Spaces.html |archivedate=December 6, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Next to the Center is the Forest Lodge, built in 2005 as the primary center for overnight stays in the Forest. Sixty people can spend the night here, sleeping four to eight to a room. A central Commons can accommodate 140 for lectures and 65 for meals prepared in the kitchen, and the deck offers a view of the surrounding mountains.{{cite web|title=Forest Lodge|url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/teacher-student-resources/HousingResources/ForestLodge.html|accessdate=January 29, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206060617/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/teacher-student-resources/HousingResources/ForestLodge.html|archivedate=December 6, 2007|df=mdy-all}} The third building in this main complex is the [[solar energy|Solar]] Pavilion, on a small rise behind the Science Center. It is an unwalled shelter built of [[red pine]] harvested within the forest. Its 32 [[Photovoltaic module|solar panels]] on its sloping, south-facing roof, which when combined with 48 more on the Center for Science and Education provided 26,000 [[kilowatt hour]]s of electricity in their first 11 months of operation, about half the building's total demand. During daylight in summer it can provide all the building's power.{{cite web |title=Solar panels |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/SolarPanels.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206055819/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/GreenBuildings/SolarPanels.html |archivedate=December 6, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Underneath the roof are two large picnic tables and real-time monitors for the solar power system to allow the Pavilion's use as an outdoor classroom. Away from this complex are two other buildings. The 1834 Chatsfield Stone House, located along the Continental Road between Arthurs and Tamarack ponds, the only remaining structure from the area's past uses, was rebuilt after a 1912 fire and is now a museum. Its exhibits relate not only to the past human uses of the forest but to its natural history, and include a short nearby interpretive trail designed to teach tree identification. Some educational programs are based here, and it too can be used for overnight stays (albeit without electricity or running water) with forest permission. ===Programs and projects=== The consortium runs several regular programs and projects in conjunction with its member institutions. A Small Grants program, funded by the [[Ernst C. Stiefel Foundation]], has been in place since 1990, continuing a similar practice of Harvard's.{{cite web |title=Small Grants |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/SmallGrants/index.html |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209093133/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/SmallGrants/index.html |archivedate=December 9, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Teachers and researchers at member institutions are eligible for up to $3,000 for educational projects and $5,000 for research projects. A total of $425,000 has been given out since then.{{cite web |title=Grants Given to Date |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/SmallGrants/GrantstoDate.html |accessdate=January 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509165236/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/scientist-resources/SmallGrants/GrantstoDate.html |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} The School in the Forest program, funded initially by a grant from the [[New York Community Trust]], brings students from urban public schools in New York City to the forest for day or overnight trips to get the same experience the consortium's member schools and school districts enjoy for their students. Currently P.S 220 in the [[Mott Haven, Bronx|Mott Haven]] section of the [[Bronx]] and P.S/I.S 311 from [[Inwood, Manhattan|Inwood]], the northern tip of [[Manhattan]] Island, are participating.{{cite web |title=School in the Forest |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/schoolintheforest/index.html |accessdate=January 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121184515/http://www.blackrockforest.org/docs/about-the-forest/schoolintheforest/index.html |archivedate=November 21, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} The weekend of April 29, 2011, the Marine Biology Research Program of the Urban Assembly [[New York Harbor School]] headed to Black Rock Forest to take part in ecosystem ecology projects.{{cite web |url=http://newyorkharborschool.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Newsletter-Spring-2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531205134/http://newyorkharborschool.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Newsletter-Spring-2011.pdf |archivedate=May 31, 2011 |df=mdy }} In the mid-1990s, Jean Gardner, a consortium consultant, began putting together a Virtual Forest Initiative, a new concept designed to take advantage of the possibilities of the then-emerging [[World Wide Web]]. It would not only allow visitors to take a "virtual hike" through the forest, it would also provide real-time data from the forest's environmental monitoring network to enhance appreciation of its ecological importance.{{cite news |last=Muschamp |first=Herbert |authorlink=Herbert Muschamp |title= ARCHITECTURE VIEW;In Cyberspace, Seeing the Forest for the Trees |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/25/arts/architecture-view-in-cyberspace-seeing-the-forest-for-the-trees.html?sq=Black+Rock+Forest+Muschamp&scp=1&st=nyt |newspaper=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=February 25, 1996 |accessdate=January 30, 2008}} In April 2004 a virtual hike with data was made available,{{cite web |title=Black Rock Forest Virtual Hike |url=http://icp.giss.nasa.gov/education/modules/carbon/topic1/ |date=April 2004 |accessdate=January 30, 2008}} in addition to the clickable map on the Consortium's website.{{cite web |title=Clickable Map |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/html-files/imagemap.html |accessdate=January 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509142133/http://www.blackrockforest.org/html-files/imagemap.html |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} The first "Green Ride", a three-day, 260-mile (418 km) [[bicycling]] trip from [[Fort Tryon Park]] in Manhattan to the forest and back, was held in October 2007.{{cite journal |title=The 'Green Ride' Raises $48,000 for Forest Education Programs |journal=Black Rock Forest News |volume=XVIII |issue=1 |page=1 |date=Winter 2008 |url=http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/Newsletter-Winter2008.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=January 31, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512000953/http://www.blackrockforest.org/pdf-files/Newsletter-Winter2008.pdf |archivedate=May 12, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} It was successful in raising $60,000 for forest programs and will be held again in 2008.{{cite web |title=The Green Ride |url=http://www.thegreenride.org/ |accessdate=January 31, 2008}} ===Consortium member institutions and organizations=== The following institutions are members of the consortium:{{cite web |title=Members |url=http://blackrockforest.org/about/member-institutions |accessdate=January 25, 2017}} *[[American Museum of Natural History]] *[[Avenues: The World School]] *[[Barnard College]] *The [[Browning School]] *The [[Calhoun School]] *[[Central Park Conservancy]] *[[Columbia University]] *[[Cornwall Central School District]] *[[The Dalton School]] *[[Metropolitan Montessori School]] *[[New York - New Jersey Trail Conference]] *[[New York University]] ([[Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development]], and [[New York University College of Arts and Science|School of Arts and Sciences]]) *[[Newburgh Enlarged City School District]] *[[The School at Columbia University]] *[[The Spence School]] *[[Storm King School]] *[[Trevor Day School]] *[[Urban Assembly School for Applied Math and Science]] ==Access== Most access to Black Rock Forest comes from Route 9W to the east, where there are three separate parking areas along the southbound roadway of the [[divided highway]]. The main entrance and [[parking lot]] is on Reservoir Road near [[Storm King School]] and [[Cornwall on Hudson]]'s Deer Hill section. From there it is a half-mile (1 km) via trail or road to the Center for Science and Education. A mile (1.6 km) north of that is the entrance opposite the old headquarters building on Continental Road, with more limited parking, and several miles to the south, just north of the USMA property, there is another small parking lot aside 9W. Three other entry points exist. From the south, along [[New York State Route 293|NY 293]] a mile south of Route 9W, a trail from the end of a short road leads from the military reservation into the forest. On the northwest side, there is another trailhead near the end of Mine Hill Road, a dead-end street off Angola Road, and finally there is the access from Old Mineral Springs Road at the western corner. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.blackrockforest.org Black Rock Forest Consortium website] *[http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~kastens/curriculum/BRF/ Student Investigations using Data from the Environmental Sensors at the Black Rock Forest] [[Category:Nature reserves in New York (state)]] [[Category:Protected areas of Orange County, New York]] [[Category:Forest research institutes]] [[Category:U.S. Route 9W]] [[Category:Protected areas of the Hudson Highlands]] [[Category:Cornwall, New York]] [[Category:Highlands, New York]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in New York (state)]]
